subject: Art
title: Saturation
description: The intensity or purity of a color â€” from vivid to muted.

hook.text: A fire truck is vivid red. A brick wall is muted red. Same hue, completely different feel. The difference? Saturation â€” the intensity dial of color.

buildup.text: High saturation: pure, vivid, intense â€” straight from the tube. Low saturation: muted, grayed, subdued â€” mixed with gray or its complement. Zero saturation: pure gray, no color at all.

discovery.text: Most of nature is low to medium saturation. Earth, skin, stone, wood â€” all muted. High saturation exists in flowers, birds, and sunsets. If your painting is all high saturation, it looks unnatural and overwhelming.

twist.text: A small area of high saturation surrounded by low saturation pops like a jewel. This is how you create visual excitement â€” not by making everything vivid, but by making one thing vivid against a muted context.

climax.text: Take any vivid color and gradually mix in gray. Watch it go from intense to neutral. That gradient IS saturation. Understanding it gives you control over mood.

punchline.text: Saturation is the volume knob of color. Don't leave it at maximum.

quiz.question: How do you lower the saturation of a color?
options: Mix with gray or its complementary color
Add more of the same color
